content.value_statement: Students often struggle to use AI effectively without over-relying on it. This framework provides structured methods to integrate AI as a collaborative learning partner through the Three Roles approach, ensuring students learn from AI while maintaining independent capability.

prompt_templates.title: Explain Concept
prompt_templates.prompt: I'm learning [TOPIC]. Explain [SPECIFIC CONCEPT] in this code: [PASTE CODE]. Focus on: [WHAT YOU DON'T UNDERSTAND]. I understand [WHAT YOU DO UNDERSTAND].

prompt_templates.title: Debug My Code
prompt_templates.prompt: This code should [EXPECTED BEHAVIOR] but instead [ACTUAL BEHAVIOR]. Code: [PASTE]. I tried: [ATTEMPTS]. My hypothesis: [HYPOTHESIS]. What's wrong and why?

prompt_templates.title: Review My Work
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this code focusing on: [ASPECT 1], [ASPECT 2], [ASPECT 3]. Code: [PASTE]. Please suggest improvements and explain WHY each matters.

prompt_templates.title: Explore Alternatives
prompt_templates.prompt: I solved [PROBLEM] using [APPROACH]. Code: [PASTE]. What are alternative approaches? Compare pros/cons. When would you use each?

output_examples.input: Create a lesson plan for teaching Python functions with AI assistance
output: Foundation Phase (40%, No AI): Introduce function syntax, parameters, return values. Students write 3 functions independently.
AI-Assisted Phase (40%, Encouraged): Use AI to explain unclear functions, generate test cases, explore variations.
Verification Phase (20%, No AI): Write 2 new functions without AI. Explain all functions including AI-generated ones.

best_practices: Always include AI-free foundational phases before introducing AI assistance
Require students to explain AI-generated code before using it
Implement the 20-minute rule: students must struggle independently before asking AI
Create verification checkpoints that test independent capability
anti_patterns: Using AI without first building foundational skills independently
Accepting AI code without reading, testing, and understanding it
Allowing AI use during verification or assessment phases
Failing to disclose AI assistance in submitted work

faq.question: Which AI tools work with this framework?
faq.answer: This methodology works with any AI assistant including Claude, ChatGPT, GitHub Copilot, and similar tools.

faq.question: What balance is recommended for beginners?
faq.answer: Beginners should use 60% foundational work, 20% AI-assisted, and 20% verification. Increase AI usage as skills develop.

faq.question: How do I prevent students from over-relying on AI?
faq.answer: Implement the 20-minute rule, require explanation of all AI code, and include regular AI-free assessments.

faq.question: Does this work for non-programming subjects?
faq.answer: The Three Roles Framework applies broadly. The scripts and templates are programming-focused but principles transfer.

faq.question: How do I verify students learned from AI assistance?
faq.answer: Use AI-free checkpoints where students solve similar problems independently and explain all code in their own words.

faq.question: How does this compare to traditional pair programming?
faq.answer: AI pair programming follows similar dynamics but AI roles are more flexible. Student drives more of the learning direction.
